                    Text: 
                    U.S. FEDERAL LEGAL SUMMARY Ketamine REGULATED Yes STATUS Scheduled SCHEDULE Schedule III CLASSIFICATION Depressant SCH. DATE Aug 12, 1999

Ketamine was unscheduled up until August 1999. In early July 1999 the DEA added Ketamine to schedule III with an emergency ruling...which took effect August 12, 1999. Ketamine is now federally illegal to possess in the United States without a license or prescription. Ketamine nasal spray was approved by the FDA in 2019 under the brand name Spravato containing only the enantiomer esketamine, as a therapeutic drug for "treatment-resistant depression. See FDA Press Release (Mar 5, 2019) Ketamine is being studied for medical utility around the world. The medical research may eventually result in changes to the legal status. Because ketamine is an approved drug in most countries, it is already being used "off label" for treatment of depression and other indications in clinics around the world.

U.S. STATE LAW #


                    Context: 
                    This section provides a detailed summary of U.S. federal and state legal status for ketamine, including its Schedule III classification since August 1999, its medical approval as Spravato in 2019, and variations in state laws. It is relevant for understanding ketamine’s legal framework within the broader discussion of drugs and chemicals covered in the webpage.

                    Text: 
                    U.S. STATE LAW #

Over the past two years, ketamine has been scheduled in many states, and laws are pending in many more. Now that Ketamine is federally illegal, it is expected that most states will also eventually schedule it. If ketamine is not scheduled in a specific state, all prosecutions for possession or sales would have to happen at the federal level.

INTERNATIONAL LAW #

In January 2016, the World Health Organization Expert Committee on Drug Dependence recommended that ketamine not be placed under international control. [read more] Australia #

Schedule IV (Search for Ketamine) and Sydney Star Observer article, Aug 2004

Austria #

Ketamine is not a controlled substance (not listed in the SMG (Suchmittelgesetz)), but requires a prescripition to obtain legally. (thanks pw) (last updated Sep 28, 2013)

Belgium #

Ketamine is legal only for medical or veterinary use with a prescription, and possession can result in arrest.

Brazil #

                    Text: 
                    Canada #

Ketamine is Schedule 1 in Canada, pursuant to a Feb 2004 notice that it "is an analogue of phencyclidine (PCP), and is, therefore, captured as item 14 in Schedule I of the CDSA and item 14 in the Narcotic Control Regulations (NCR)..." Affected researchers were expected to have complied with Schedule 1 protocol for the handling of ketamine by August 31, 2005. See Amendment to Food and Drugs Act, SOR/2005-270 August 31, 2005 and Notice: Status of ketamine under the CDSA [PDF].

Cambodia #

Reportedly sold over-the-counter, but rarely available. (unconfirmed) (thanks RHCN)

China #

Ketamine is a class II psychiatric drug; trade is limited to licensed wholesalers and retail sales are prohibited. In Jul 2004, the state of Sichuan placed ketamine in class I; other provinces are expected to follow suit. [Chinafdc-law.com] See also China firms embroiled in ketamine scandal.

Croatia #

Ketamine is controlled in Croatia. (unconfirmed) (thanks t) (last updated Nov 9, 2015)

Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Law

                    Text: 
                    U.K. (United Kingdom, UK, Great Britain) #

As of June 10, 2014 the UK made ketamine a Class B drug. See http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2014/1106/pdfs/uksi_20141106_en.pdf. Previously, ketamine became a Class C drug as of Jan 1, 2006. See http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4564606.stm and OPSI.gov.uk. The move had been expected since a spring 2004 ACMD report that recommended moving ketamine into Class C. Prior to Jan 1, 2006, Ketamine was not controlled in the U.K. under the Misuse of Drugs Act, making it legal to possess. However sales and distribution were controlled under the Medicines Act making it illegal to sell or distribute without a license. (last updated May 22, 2014)

If you have information about the legal status of this substance in any other country, please let us know.

CAUTION & DISCLAIMER #


                    Context: 
                    This chunk provides detailed legal status information for ketamine in the United Kingdom, noting its classification changes from unregulated to Class C in 2006 and then to Class B in 2014. It includes relevant legal references and updates, making it essential for understanding UK drug laws related to ketamine within the broader international law section of the document on controlled substances.
